articles.headline: A Thorn in YouTube’s Side Digs In Even Deeper
articles.snippet: Carlos Maza, a socialist who calls YouTube “deeply unethical and reckless,” is trying to bolster the video site’s left wing.
articles.abstract: Carlos Maza, a socialist who calls YouTube “deeply unethical and reckless,” is trying to bolster the video site’s left wing.
articles.lead_paragraph: Carlos Maza believes that YouTube is a destructive, unethical, reckless company that amplifies bigots and profits off fascism.

articles.headline: As Congress Prepares to Vet Judy Shelton, Worries About the Fed’s Future Mount
articles.snippet: Ms. Shelton, President Trump’s nominee to the central bank, has unconventional views. But a recent policy reversal is stoking the most concern.
articles.abstract: Ms. Shelton, President Trump’s nominee to the central bank, has unconventional views. But a recent policy reversal is stoking the most concern.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senators will vet Judy Shelton, a prominent Federal Reserve critic, for one of the central bank’s top jobs on Thursday, a moment that many economists will be watching closely because they see her as a potential threat to the Fed’s prized independence.

articles.headline: Andy Rubin’s Start-Up, Essential Products, Shuts Down
articles.snippet: The smartphone company founded by Mr. Rubin, a former Google executive, struggled to win over customers.
articles.abstract: The smartphone company founded by Mr. Rubin, a former Google executive, struggled to win over customers.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Essential Products, a consumer electronics start-up founded by the former Google executive Andy Rubin, said on Wednesday that it was ceasing operations.
articles.byline: By Daisuke Wakabayashi and Erin Griffith

articles.headline: Centrist Democrats Want to Stop Sanders. They’re Not Sure Who Can.
articles.snippet: Unless a moderate favorite soon emerges, party leaders may increasingly look to Michael R. Bloomberg as a potential savior.
articles.abstract: Unless a moderate favorite soon emerges, party leaders may increasingly look to Michael R. Bloomberg as a potential savior.
articles.lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H. — The Democratic presidential primary is entering an intensely tumultuous phase, after two early contests that have left former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. reeling and elevated Senator Bernie Sanders but failed to make any candidate a dominant force in the battle for the party’s nomination.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: After Stone Case, Prosecutors Say They Fear Pressure From Trump
articles.snippet: The episode also brought to a head tensions in the U.S. attorney’s office in Washington.
articles.abstract: The episode also brought to a head tensions in the U.S. attorney’s office in Washington.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For decades after Watergate, the White House treated the Justice Department with the softest of gloves, fearful that any appearance of political interference would resurrect the specter of Attorney General John Mitchell helping President Richard M. Nixon carry out a criminal conspiracy for political ends.
articles.byline: By Katie Benner, Charlie Savage, Sharon LaFraniere and Ben Protess

articles.headline: The Bloomberg Campaign Is a Waterfall of Cash
articles.snippet: The billionaire has deployed his corporation in service of his presidential bid, producing slick events and recruiting staff members with unusually high pay and other perks.
articles.abstract: The billionaire has deployed his corporation in service of his presidential bid, producing slick events and recruiting staff members with unusually high pay and other perks.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI — In a warehouse covered in murals in the Design District here, cater waiters served wine and platters of Cuban sandwiches, summer rolls and kosher pigs in a blanket. They wore all black but for red, white and blue T-shirts reading “I Like Mike Bloomberg.”

articles.headline: Biden Needs Black Voters to Lift His Campaign. But He Has Competition.
articles.snippet: Joe Biden is looking ahead to South Carolina to resurrect his candidacy. There are signs that it may be a bigger challenge after defeats in Iowa and New Hampshire.
articles.abstract: Joe Biden is looking ahead to South Carolina to resurrect his candidacy. There are signs that it may be a bigger challenge after defeats in Iowa and New Hampshire.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA, S.C. — Even before the final results from New Hampshire showed Joseph R. Biden Jr. finishing a distant fifth there, the former vice president had flown to South Carolina on Tuesday night for a gathering of enthusiastic supporters. A gospel choir sang about salvation, a fitting choice for a candidate who is counting on this state’s large black electorate to save his third try for the White House.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Saul, Astead W. Herndon and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: Iran’s Economy Is Bleak. Its Stock Market Is Soaring.
articles.snippet: The rise attests to the wealth within the country and the resourcefulness of its companies as they confront U.S. sanctions.
articles.abstract: The rise attests to the wealth within the country and the resourcefulness of its companies as they confront U.S. sanctions.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — He looked past Iran’s cratering economy, ignored the unraveling nuclear deal and tuned out the bellicose threats of war from President Trump. Maciej Wojtal was focused on a mundane yet crucial question: Where were Iran’s people going to buy their chocolate biscuits?

articles.headline: Playing on Kansas City Radio: Russian Propaganda
articles.snippet: Radio Sputnik, a propaganda arm of the Russian government, began broadcasting on three Kansas City-area radio stations during prime drive time.
articles.abstract: Radio Sputnik, a propaganda arm of the Russian government, began broadcasting on three Kansas City-area radio stations during prime drive time.
articles.lead_paragraph: When commuters spin the radio dial as they drive through Kansas City, Mo., these days, between the strains of classic rock and country hits they can tune in to something unexpected: Russian agitprop.

articles.headline: McClatchy, a Major U.S. Newspaper Chain, Files for Bankruptcy
articles.snippet: Under the plan, the hedge fund Chatham Asset Management would take over 30 newspapers nationwide, including The Sacramento Bee and The Miami Herald.
articles.abstract: Under the plan, the hedge fund Chatham Asset Management would take over 30 newspapers nationwide, including The Sacramento Bee and The Miami Herald.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was a thriving family business that got its start in 1857 as a four-page newspaper for residents of Sacramento in the wake of the gold rush. Now the McClatchy Company, the publisher of The Sacramento Bee, The Miami Herald and 28 other dailies across the country, has filed for bankruptcy and is expected to be run by a New York hedge fund.
articles.byline: By Katie Robertson and Marc Tracy
